slides.title: Go Concurrency
Concurrency vs Parallelism
slides.rawText: Concurrency vs Parallelism Concurrency Dealing with a lot of things at once. It's about structure . One worker, multiple tasks Parallelism Doing a lot of things at once. It's about execution . Multiple workers, simultaneous execution "Concurrency is about dealing with lots of things at once. Parallelism is about doing lots of things at once." ‚Äî Rob Pike

slides.title: Goroutines
slides.rawText:
Goroutines Functions that run concurrently Extremely lightweight (2KB stack) Managed by the Go Runtime (Scheduler) Cheap to create thousands of them func main () {'{'} {'
 '} // Start a new goroutine go doSomething () {'
 '} {'
 '} // Main function continues... fmt . Println ( "Hello" ) {'
}'} go

slides.title: Channels
slides.rawText: Channels "Don't communicate by sharing memory, share memory by communicating." G1 Sender chan int G2 Receiver // Send ch <- data // Receive data := <- ch

slides.title: Buffered Channels
slides.rawText: Buffered Channels Buffered channels have a capacity . Sends are non-blocking until the buffer is full. Receives are non-blocking until the buffer is empty. make(chan int, 5) [{i}] ))} {/* Filling Animation */} {[0, 1, 2].map(i => ( ))} ch := make ( chan int , 5 ) {'\n'} ch <- 1 // Doesn't block ch <- 2 // Doesn't block

slides.title: Select Statement
slides.rawText:
Select Statement Like a switch statement, but for channels. It lets a goroutine wait on multiple communication operations. select case msg1 := <-ch1: {'
 '}fmt.Println("Received", msg1) {'
'} case msg2 := <-ch2: {'
 '}fmt.Println("Received", msg2) {'
'} default : {'
 '}fmt.Println("No activity") {'
}'} üì° Multiplexing

slides.title: Sync Package
slides.rawText: Sync Package Essential primitives for synchronizing goroutines and protecting shared memory. WaitGroup Wait for a collection of goroutines to finish. G{i} ))} wg.Add(1) ... wg.Done() ... wg.Wait() Add ‚Üí Work ‚Üí Done ‚Üí Wait Mutex Mutual exclusion lock. Protect shared resources. Data Lock() Unlock() mu.Lock() ... mu.Unlock() Once Run an action exactly once, no matter how many times called. Init() once.Do(setup)

slides.title: Context Package
slides.rawText:
Context Package Essential for managing cancellation , timeouts , and deadlines across API boundaries. ‚úì Propagate cancellation signals ‚úì Set deadlines for operations ‚úì Pass request-scoped values ctx , cancel := context. WithTimeout (parent, 2*time.Second) {'
'} defer cancel () {'

'} select case <-time. After (3*time.Second): {'
 '}fmt.Println("Overslept") {'
'} case <-ctx. Done (): {'
 '}fmt.Println(ctx. Err ()) // context deadline exceeded Cancellation Propagation Parent Child {i} ))} CANCELLED!

slides.title: Worker Pools
slides.rawText: Worker Pools A pattern to control the number of goroutines processing jobs. Jobs J{i} ))} ‚Üí Workers (Fixed Pool) W{i} ))} ‚Üí Results ‚úì ))}

slides.title: Race Conditions
slides.rawText: Best Practices & Pitfalls Concurrency is powerful‚Äîbut unsafe patterns can silently crash production systems. These are the most common mistakes and how professionals avoid them. Race Conditions Multiple goroutines accessing shared memory without coordination. ‚ùó Causes flaky bugs that appear randomly and are hard to reproduce. data++ // Unsafe Deadlocks Goroutines blocked forever, waiting on each other. ‚ö†Ô∏è Application freezes with zero CPU usage. fatal error: deadlock! Race Detector Detects unsafe memory access automatically during runtime. ‚úÖ Catches bugs before they hit production. go run -race main.go Golden Rules of Concurrency Follow these principles and your concurrent programs will stay predictable, debuggable, and production-safe. ))}

slides.title: Key Takeaways
